title: This a reasonably good hotel is for its price range, on the outskirts of Pune
text:
This is a reasonably good hotel in its price range. The location is good if you want to access Baner road or Balewadi part of Pune or else you need to have a car to be mobile.
Also make sure you book to stay in the new wing. The old wing is a bit run down.
Be prepared for slightly slow service standards as staff to guests ratio is adverse.

Rooms were ok in size and reasonably well appointed, though some elements of decor esp carpets and furnishing could have been less garish.

The food at restaurant is reasonably good. There is an all day buffet. The free wifi was adequate.

title: Nice hotel near Delhi airport, excellent customer service
text: This hotel is located in AeroCity locality close to Delhi International Airport ( about 10-15 mins by car). We were using the hotel’s business centre for carrying out senior interviews and had lunch at its Citrus restaurant ( a buffet with an ample selection of dishes). The food was good, the conference facilities was adequate and customer service excellent. Recommended.

title: Nice place to have Konkani style seafood in Alibaug
text: This is restaurant is moderately priced with an air-conditioned and non-air conditioned section. The area around the restaurant is a bit congested and sometimes parking can be a problem. We ordered the fish thali, special vegetarian thali, mutton curry with wadde, and oysters masala. The thalis are good value for money and in the Konkani-style of cooking. The restaurant is relatively simple in ambience and does not serve alcohol. Worth a visit

title: Reasonably good airport hotel
text: This hotel is located in AeroCity complex close to Delhi Internatinal airport. I was reaching late at night/early morning (0100 hours) and hence wanted to stay at hotel close to the airport. The hotel had arranged a car pick up, the driver was waiting at arrival gate and I was at the hotel within 10-15 minutes. The check in process was fast and I was in my room quickly. However, what was disappointing was that though it was supposed to be a non-smoking room I could smell smoke which was lingering in the curtains and parts of the room. It was too late to change and tried to sleep the best I could. The rooms otherwise were well appointed and with usual expected amenities. The wifi was effective. The free buffet breakfast had a good spread of dishes, but since the restaurant was crowded, service was a bit slow.

title: Nice restaurant in Assagao
text:
Nice restaurant in Assagao in Goa. Interesting concept and business model.
You have to reserve and order your dishes in advance of your visit from a standard menu for the day. The fixed price includes several starters, the main course and desert. The cocktails and fruit drinks are very good but priced extra. The house speciality the smoky cocktail was unique. The food was good though the mushroom starter was extra salty.
The service was friendly. The al fresco ambience of the place was good. Overall good though slightly on the expensive side

title: Great meal at this hidden gem in Anjuna locality of Goa
text:
We had lunch at Edible Archives for a celebration. This is a great new addition to the restaurant scene in Anjuna locality about 5-10 mins from the beach by car. The restaurant which is part of a restored Goan bungalow has outdoor seating in a garden setting which is simple but elegant. The restaurant is open from about 11 am onward till 11 pm. Chef Anu Mitra has modelled the restaurant on the farm to fork concept and hence the vegetables and meats are fresh and organic. We sampled the vegetarian selection today including 3 starters/small plates and their amazing veg bowl. The small plate included superb green beans and Aubergine dish with peanuts and soy sauce. The drinks and cocktail selection is good as well. I tried for the first time the local Hapusa gin with tonic. The service was attentive and courteous, without being obtrusive. Very relaxed but satisfying meal which is amazing value for money. Next time will sample the fish dishes.
Strongly recommended.

title: Nice ambience, good food
text: We went to the restaurant for a meal on Christmas Day for lunch and had an enjoyable experience. The restaurant has many branches in Pune but the largest is the one in Koregaon park. The food is largely a range of eastern cuisines and they have a good selection of drinks. The restaurant has outside section in the garden and a covered section which is air conditioned. The service is reasonably fast.

title: This is very good vegetarian restaurant serving far eastern cuisines
text: This is very good vegetarian restaurant serving dishes inspired by far eastern cuisines . It is located in the Poes Garden locality of Chennai. The food is very good and service is attentive and courteous. Recommended

title: Nice hotel close to Chennai International Airport
text:
This is probably the first Trident Hotel ( owned by the Oberoi hotels) so is slightly different compared to the business hotels in Mumbai/Delhi but the service levels are similar. The hotel is about 10-15 minutes from Chennai airport is good value for money for its range of services.
The rooms are reasonably large with usual amenities with good views of old mango trees outside the window. The free wifi is effective and the breakfast buffet has good spread of Indian and western dishes. The service levels are very good.

title: Worth visiting to the cats don’t jump any more
text: This was once famous as the “Jumping cats monastery “. However, on our visit we saw only one cat, and no it didn’t jump. The monastery is very beautiful with lovely wood carvings and wonderful wooden meditation hall

title: Inle Lake’s main shrine
text: This is Inle lake’s main shrine. It holds five Buddhas that are now unrecognisable under interminable layers of lumpy gold leaf.

title: This usually forms part of any Lake visit by boat
text: The Intha of Inle Lake are famous their amazingly productive vegetables beds, made by piling weeds and compost on long poles fixed to lake floor. When we visited we saw a lot of green tomatoes in the floating gardens

title: One highlight of visit to Inle Lake
text:
Indien village can be easily included as an add on to day long lake trip or taken separately if required by boat or car. We accessed it by a long tail motor boat popular in the region, operated by local driver come guide. The village is one the largest settlements around Inle and is site one of the busiest 5 day rotating markets ( please note market starts early around 0800 and ends by about 1100 and moves from village to village and so obtain a schedule in advance so as not miss out)
It is also the site of the Shwe Inthien Stupa complex which is similar to Kukka Pagoda complex but also worth visiting . It is about a 20 min walk or shorter drive to this complex from the village. The stupas were mostly built in 17th and 18 centuries and there about 1000 plus stupas, which when seen together is stunning.

title: Simply stunning
text: Must visit day trip from Inle to Kakku Pagoda complex via the colonial town of Taunggyi. The round trip with stops lunch and visit to the Pagoda complex can take about 6-7 hours to do at a leisurely pace. The complex which is near village Mway Taw has thousands of medieval stupas in walled compound. There about 2500+ stupas, most were originally built in the 11th-13th centuries but a few are believed to have built by emperor Ashoka in 3rd century BC.

title: Stop for a while enroute to Pindaya Caves or return from
text: Worth stopping by at the lake at one restaurant to have lunch or a short bite or to drink coffee or beer lazily watching the view of the lake

title: Must visit as day trip from Inle
text: Pindaya caves can be best accessed by car ( it’s about 1 1/2 to 2 hour drive from Nyaungshwe). We were able ask our hotel to hire a car with driver for trip for about 30000 kyats ( or USD 20). We left at about 1000 and returned back about 1700 ( we stopped at few places on the way as drive was scenic : we stopped a local crafts workshop and old colonial railway station/bridge). The caves themselves are awe inspiring .Pindaya is a complex of 3 caverns, largest about 150 metres high. It has become a major Buddhist pilgrimage place due to 8000 + Buddha statues of various sizes and styles. Looking at the them at first sight is truly spellbinding. The access to the cave can be by a covered pathway of steps or via a lift/elevator. Entry fee to the Pindaya area is about $5 per person and to caves an additional 3000 kyats per person.

title: This is the best restaurant for lunch on a trip to Pindaya caves
text: This is the best restaurant for lunch on a day trip to Pindaya caves. The food is reasonably good, service is a bit slow ( the place is usually full of tourists) but views of the lake are amazing. Other benefits for tourists you can pay by credit card, and there is ATM on the complex. Reserve ahead for tables facing the lake

title: Cosy restaurant with reasonably good food
text: This restaurant which is located the main road ( Yone Gyi Street) of Nyaungshwe is quite popular with tourists all day long. It is cosy place to hang out and coffee/beer or come for quick bite for lunch/dinner. We had mix of pitta bread and hummus, and a pizza. They didn’t have wine on that day, so we had local beer.

title: Nice multi-cuisine restaurant with great views of Canal
text: This restaurant which is on the first floor of Hotel Viewpoint Ecolodge is worth a visit for its reasonably good food, nice ambience and great views of the canal. We were staying at hotel and went for dinner on one of days and we had a good experience. We had a mix of cuisines ( avacado salad, pasta, and Shan Prawn curry with steamed rice); the food made the cut but was not outstanding. The vegetarian menu was a bit limited though. We drank local beer and wine.

title: A great place to stop for lunch on visit to Inle Lake
text: A great place to stop for lunch on a visit to Inle Lake. We had the grilled fish in a banana leaf, grilled vegetables and a salad. The food was fresh and tasted great. The service was a little slow, as the restaurant was crowded, but was courteous and helpful. The views from the restaurant of the lake, the paddy fields and the hills nearby were amazing.

title: Surprisingly good place for Indian food in Nyaungshwe
text: This restaurant, which is owned by a Nepali family, is good place for value for money Indian food. The restaurant which is on the Main Street in Nyaungshwe town, is a popular place and can get crowded in the evening. Most of the dishes we ordered ( all vegetarian) were surprisingly good. The restaurant has a cosy look and feel to it and the service is customer centric though at an amiable pace.

title: Nice place to stop on way to Kakku Pagoda complex for lunch or a short break
text: This is a nice stop for lunch on a day visit to Pagoda complex at Kakku, close to the colonial town of Taunggyi. The food is fairly good, with great views of the valley and vineyards. The wine is also surprisingly good ( if you keep your expectations right). We had lunch at the restaurant but we were told this a great place to watch the sunset tasting their local wine.

title: One of the highlights of our Myanmar visit
text: This place is must visit on a trip to Myanmar. There are some nice hotels on the lake itself but we preferred to stay at a lovely hotel at Nyaungshwe town with good access to the lake by boat but also to explore the town of Nyaungshwe and do day visits to the Kakku Pagoda complex and the awe inspiring Pindaya caves. A trip to Inle Lake and it’s wonderful sights by long tail boat was simply amazing. Plan for about 7-8 hrs which includes seeing the floating market, several pagodas in stilted villages on the lake, having lunch in a stilted restaurant, visiting the small local workshops making silverware, textiles, etc and the Stupa complex at the town of Indein.

title: A lovely hotel, well located explore Inle Lake and nearby areas
text: We stayed in this hotel for 3 nights and enjoyed our stay. Most of the hotel is wonderfully designed with views of the waterways, the hills in the background and lotus pond all around ( even if the pink of the cottages is bit over the top and difficult to fathom in the day light hours, but it grows on you in the twilight hours). The hotel is not on the lake, on the canal which leads to the lake, and this from our point view was as it is a short walk to the shops and restaurants of Nyaungshwe town. The hotel can organise a boat to take you to lake by boat, or a taxi for a half-day visit (s), both which are must to Pingaya caves and ancient Pagoda complex at Kakku. The hotel is in way a resort, though on a smaller scale. The rooms are spacious, well designed and with usual amenities, the service is courteous and helpful and the wifi is effective in rooms and in most parts of the hotel. The buffet breakfast is reasonably good, though it could be better. The hotel also has spa which we did not use. Recommended.

title: This is probably the best restaurant in Bagan
text: This was the best restaurant we visited in Bagan and among the best on our Myanmar trip. It is located in Nyaung-U town not far from the Shwezigon Pagoda. This garden restaurant is quadrangular in design with a garden in the middle courtyard. There is an outside and air conditioned seating area. The concept is not new of organic, farm to plate, food but Sharky’s have executed it very well. The food was very good and service was excellent. Recommended

title: Nice Italian restaurant in Nyaung-U, though on expensive side
text: Nice Italian restaurant in Nyaung-U town, though slightly on the expensive side. We had dinner here on one of the nights we were in Bagan. It is has an outside seating area and a covered seating area. While we initially sitting outside we had to the inside area as one of the guest was smoking. The food was good but not outstanding and the service was friendly though slightly laid back.

title: Imposing Bagan temple, currently under restoration
text: This temple which is an imposing 150 foot tall, is located on the road between Bagan and Nyaung-U. The temple is three stories tall, and is built with red brick. It was built in the 13th century by the eponymous king. On the first floor of the temple, there are four Buddhas that face each direction. Its upper structure is currently under restoration. Worth a visit.

title: A great place visit and also see sunset over Irrawaddy river
text: This is a small temple and a bulbous shaped stupa overlooking the Irrawaddy river at a height. It is one of oldest temples in Bagan having been built in the 2nd century. The original pagoda was completely destroyed in an earthquake in 1975 but has now been re-built and is in good condition. It is a great place to watch the sunset over the Irrawaddy river.

title: One of the largest temples in Bagan
text: This temple which is easily accessible from Bagan ( by taxi, Tuk Tuk or E-bike) is one the largest in Bagan. It is large pyramid like structure visible from far. It has an interesting past - the king who built the temple came to power by assassinating his father and elder brother. He later also killed his Bengali queen, whose father sent mercenaries and had him killed.

title: Don’t miss the reclining Buddha statue in one the temples by the main Stupa
text: The pagoda is easily accessible in Old Bagan and contains a series of five terraces, topped with a cylindrical stupa, which has a bejewelled umbrella. Earlier it was a spot popular with tourists to watch the sunset but after an accident climbing the terraces is not allowed. It is still worth a visit also for seeing the elongated reclining Buddha statue in one of the temples on the side of the main Stupa.

title: One of largest temple complexes in Bagan, worth visiting
text: This temple is located in the village of Nyaung-U . It is a large temple complex, which can be quite crowded as it is revered by Buddhists, as it is believed to enshrine a bone and tooth of Buddha. It consists of a circular gold leaf-gilded stupa surrounded by smaller temples and shrines. At the entrance to the pagoda there are huge statues of lion shaped guardians of the temple.

title: One of the best temples in Bagan, almost fully reatored
text: This temple is easily accessible in Old Bagan. If you are staying near Tharabar Gate it is walking distance ( about 5-10 mins). During the day it with direct sunlight it can be quite hot so bring an umbrella. The Temple has been restored and is probably the best maintained of the Bagan temples. The temple houses four standing Buddhas, each one facing the cardinal direction of East, North, West and South. The temple is an architectural marvel fusing local Mon and (South) Indian style of architecture.

title: Highlight of visit to Bagan
text: Bagan temples is highlight of our visit to this ancient city and a UNESCO World Heritage Site. During the 11th and 13th centuries, 4,446 Buddhist temples, pagodas and monasteries were constructed in the Bagan plains alone, of which the remains of 3822 temples and pagodas still survive to the present day. We got a sense of the landscape of Bagan and its temples by a balloon ride in the morning followed a visit to the main temples over 2 days. We started with Ananda temple which is one of Old Bagan temples which well restored and then we saw sunset over the Irrawaddy river from the Bu Paya temple. The next day we visited the imposing three-storied Htilominlo Temple, which is currently being restored, the Upali Thein and red bricked Khaymigha temples nearby towards Old Bagan on the road from Nyaung-U. Later in day we visited the largest of Bagan temples Dhammayangi ( famous for its paired Buddha statues ), the Shwesandaw pagoda which contains a series of five terraces, topped with a cylindrical stupa, which has a bejewelled umbrella, and the tall Thatbyinnyu temple. Finally we visited the Shwezigon temple located in Nyaung-U village which is probably largest temple complex in Bagan. It is a circular gold leaf-gilded stupa surrounded by smaller temples and shrines.

title: A lovely resort hotel in Old Bagan, well located close to main temples
text:
This is lovely resort hotel in Old Bagan, well located close to main temples. It was probably the best hotel property we stayed in Bagan- aesthetically designed to blend in with surroundings, spacious rooms with an ethnic touch to design but with modern fittings, and very good service. The free wifi was also surprisingly effective in the rooms and most of the lobby and pool areas. The free buffet breakfast had a good spread of western and local dishes, with options for eggs on order.
Strongly recommended.
place: The Hotel At Tharabar Gate Bagan

title: This is all day dining restaurant at the Wyndham Grand
text:
The breakfast was excellent with an amazing spread of Burmese , Japanese , Asian and Western dishes.
We also had lunch on one of the days and the Burmese Prawn curry was superb. We also ordered the semolina and coconut desert which was nice. The service was responsive and prompt

title: Nice place to have a drink and eat in the shopping & commercial complex next to Wyndham Grand hotel
text: The beer is very good ( we had the Indian Pale ale) and all the food we had was surprisingly good as well including the Red Dot Burger, pasta and grilled vegetable. The service was reasonably quick and friendly. Recommended.

title: Traditional market in downtown Yangon
text: The market which was earlier called Scott market is worth a visit. Several hours can easily be spent at this historic covered market, with over 2000 stalls selling everything from gold and diamond jewellery, textiles and local handicrafts. Note that market is closed on Mondays and open on other days between 0830 and 5 pm.

title: Botahtaung Pagoda famous for sacred hair relic of Buddha
text: The Botataung Pagoda (Means literally "1000 military officers") is a famous pagoda located in downtown Yangon, near the Yangon river. The pagoda is hollow within, and houses what is believed to be a sacred hair of Gautama Buddha.. The Pagoda was completely destroyed during World War II, by RAF bombing and was rebuilt after the war. The cost of entry for foreigners is 6000 kyats per person. It definitely worth a visit

title: The pagoda at centre of downtown Yangon
text: Sule Pagoda is a Burmese stupa located in the heart of downtown Yangon, occupying the centre of the city close to the Town Hall and the independence monument. It is believed to be more than 2600 years old. Worth a visit . For foreigners the entrance fee is 5000 kyats per person.

title: A modern style hotel located close Kandawgyi Lake, with great views of the lake
text:
A modern style hotel located close Kandawgyi Lake, with great views of the lake and the adjacent park as well as of Shwedagon Pagoda. It’s spanking new, and looks like any other hotel in a big city in Asia and lacks the ethnic charm of some others . The rooms are spacious but ask for those with Lake view. The amenities in the room include Nespresso machine and bathrooms are also modern with bath tub facing the lake !!
The free wifi was effective and the buffet breakfast was elaborate with a wide selection of Burmese, Japanese, Asian and western options. The service was courteous and helpful. The hotel has a bus which does scheduled drops and pick up from airport and downtown area.

title: Fairly good restaurant for Continental food in Yangon
text: This is restaurant in downtown Yangon, located in the Loft Hotel. The ambience of the restaurant and the service was good. It has reasonable vegetarian selection of dishes. The soup, salad and pasta we ordered were good but the Burmese food ( Prawn curry) was bland and should have been better. The dessert ( chocolate profiteroles) was very good. If you are staying at hotel you should check out this restaurant though they need to step up a bit on the Burmese cuisine.

title: Wonderful lake, with a well maintained park worth visiting
text: Kandawgyi Lake is one of two major lakes in Yangon and is located east of the Shwedagon Pagoda. It is ~8 km in circumference, and is surrounded by the Kandawgyi Nature Park and the Yangon Zoological Gardens, which consists of a zoo, an aquarium and an amusement park. It is a great place for a walk in the evening or morning. We were staying at the new Wyndham Grand hotel which is very close to the lake and has great views of the Lake and the Shwedagon Pagoda

title: Worth visiting this low key monument to see tomb of the Last Mughal
text: We walked to the tomb of Bahadur Shah Zafar II, the last Mughal Emperor, who was exiled in Rangoon by the British after the Indian Rebellion of 1857. Zafar's unassuming tomb is in a quiet avenue in Yangon not too far from the famous Shwedagon Pagoda. Zafar was not only the last Mughal but was a Urdu poet and is now revered as a Sufi saint. Worth visiting for those interested in history.

title: This was the highlight of our Yangon visit
text: Best time to see the Shwedagon Pagoda is in the night when it is beautifully lit and the weather is much cooler. It is located west of Kandawgyi Lake and at 100 m in height it dominates the Yangon skyline. It is probably the most sacred Buddhist pagoda in Myanmar and maybe the world. It therefore can get quite crowded with local worshipers. There is a separate entrance for foreigners, where they can take of their shoes, pay entrance fee of 10,000 kyats per person and be taken by lifts to the main pagoda complex. It is quite awe inspiring to see the main gold-plated dome, which is topped by a stupa containing over 7,000 diamonds, rubies, topaz and sapphires.

title: Lovely boutique hotel in heart of Yangon
text:
We stayed one night at the Loft . It is boutique hotel located close to the centre of Yangon, not far from Bogyoke Aung San Market (~10 mins walk), the Sule Pagoda/Independence Monument (15 mins walk) or the Shwedagon Pagoda ( 30 mins walk or a short taxi ride). The hotel is designed very aesthetically in minimalist way but with a ethnic touch which is pleasing. The rooms are fairly large and good value for money. The rooms are furnished well and have the usual amenities. The free wifi was effective both in rooms and lobby area. We could not sample the buffet breakfast as we had to catch an early morning flight. The hotel was helpful in providing us with packed sandwiches and fruit. The service of the hotel staff was friendly, helpful and responsive. We had slight problem with the air conditioning our room at night but it was attended quickly without much fuss.
Overall strongly recommended

title: One the best hotels in South Delhi, service orientation is superb
text:
I stayed here after several years, though I have visited the bar, coffee shop and restaurants more recently. What impressed me most was the customer service. The room are not very large ( it is one of the older hotels ) though after renovation modern, well furnished, and with usual five star amenities. The free buffet breakfast spread was varied with many options.
The hotel is well located, not to far from the airport or most of the New Delhi’s tourist areas.
A great place to stay and also is nice conference venue

title: This is one the best Asian fine dining restaurants in Pune.
text: It has mix of Chinese, Japanese and Thai cuisines and is on the ground floor of Conrad Hotel near Koregaon Park. The ambience is bright and modern and not the usual Oriental look. The staff are well trained to guide guests on different aspects of the menu. We had the miso soup, the spicy prawn hargao and spicy crisp lotus root as starters and pork belly teriyaki and vegetable udon noodles as part of the main course. The food was consistently very good and service outstanding. The staff when they learnt of a birthday in our group served us a lovely chocolate cake which was complimentary. Recommended.

title: It’s the coffee shop of the Taj Colaba
text: I have been coming to this restaurant on and off for the last 40 + years. I have not been here for lunch for while and probably came this time too because the specialty restaurants of the Taj were not yet open at 11 am. It is a multi-cuisine all day/night restaurant ( in the old days it was always seen as the coffee shop of the Taj, which it probably still is). We decided to chose Indian dishes and were not disappointed. The service was reasonably fast ( it restaurant was very busy at the time we went) and courteous.

title: Nice, aesthetically designed cafe with all day dining menu
text: Nice, aesthetically designed cafe with all day dining menu. It has an inside air conditioned area and a outside, covered area. Since it was pleasant weather we sat outside. The food is a mix of cuisines but whatever we ordered was consistently very good, though all vegetarian only. We had the upside down Upma, falafel pita pocket (sandwich), smoked jalapeño burger, and Sicilia pizza. The service was courteous and reasonably fast, except for one dish which took inordinately longer than the others. Would go again.

title: Must visit on a Ladakh trip
text: Most travellers on a visit to Ladakh tend to go to Leh and additionally to Nubra Valley and Pangong Tso. I would strongly recommend a trip to see the Dras ( Kargil) War memorial . While the journey is about 6 hours by car there is a lot to see on the way as well. The visit to the Dras War memorial is truly special. It makes us think of how much we owe our Armed Forces. “Never has so much owed by so many to so few.” Its really an amazing place, in a valley surrounded by mountain peaks on all sides. The memorial itself is in a well maintained garden with lovely flowers. It consists of the Amar Jawan Jyoti and the memorial to the soldiers who lost their lives in Kargill war, a museum which tells the story of the war, among other exhibits. There is a recently added sound and light show and a video documentary which is also worth seeing.

title: Top of the world feeling at Khardungla Pass
text: Khardungla Pass is one the highest motorable passages in the world at 17,600 feet. The journey from Leh to Nubra Valley requires you to pass through Khardungla. The journey typically takes about 4 hours but when we went it was snowing and some vehicles started slipping as they were negotiating the last leg of journey to the pass which was covered with snow. As result traffic was held up till each vehicle attached chains to rear wheels. As result the journey took about 2 hours more upto our hotel in Hunder. The pass is in a sense top of the world and when we reached there it was cold and we had tea at the cafe and took photos next to Khardungla Pass signpost.

title: Carved Buddha statue in Mulbekh Monastery is amazing
text: Just 45 km short of Kargil on the Leh-Kargil road is a place called Mulbekh which is famous for its rock carved Buddha ( reminiscent of Bamiyan Buddha carvings in Afghanistan). It's within a small temple on the left side of the road. The carved Buddha on a rock face is of a standing Maitreya Buddha ( or Future Buddha) and is worth a stop. There are couple of restaurants on the right side of the temple where you can have tea or a soft drink.

title: Amazing Monastery in Lamayuru village
text:
Around one hour from Alchi on Leh-Kargil road you will reach Lamayuru. The Monastery which is one of the oldest in Ladakh is also quite unique and amazingly perched on a rocks . There is not much walking or climbing involved as vehicles can reach close to the monastery entrance. However, views of the hills/mountains and Moonland from the monastery are quite spectacular. The best photographs of the monastery can be taken from the road just before you drive to top of hill where the monastery is located.
MoonLand which are strange but beautiful landscape is quite close to the monastery on the Leh side. Some say the soil here is very similar to that on the moon.

title: Great place to visit especially in evening
text: Nubra valley has sand dunes which provides a desert experience. One way to have in the evening when it is cooler is to watch or ride double humped camels in the sand dunes. Another option is dune bashing on ATVs ( no need to go to Dubai for this !)

title: Great place to stop on way to Kargil or to stay to get way from hustle bustle of Leh town
text: Uley Eco Resort is an amazing place to stop for a cup of coffee/ tea & freshen up, just ahead of Khalse in a place called Alchi....around 2hr from Leh on the Leh -Kargil road. It is built on a cliff edge overlooking the Indus River in an apple orchard. We stopped for coffee and had perched in Gazebo.... at a height with amazing views of the Indus River and mountains on all sides. But if you wish to get away from city and relax or prefer to go treks nearby the resort has a number of cottages for hire.

title: Definitely Worth visiting this Monastery
text: Hemis monastery is one of the oldest monasteries in Ladakh and has existed before the 11th century. It is further down from Tiksey monastery on the Leh- Srinagar road and about 45 km from Leh. Hemis monastery also has a museum as part of its complex which is worth visiting. It has many statues of Buddha in various forms including Maitreya, Tara, etc. There are a number of temples and prayer halls as part of the monastery. The one which fascinated me most was the one dedicated to and with a statue of Lord Padmasambhava ( Guru Rinpoche), believed to be a reincarnate of Buddha. The annual Hemis festival honouring Padmasambhava is held every year.

title: Probably the nearest significant monastery to Leh
text:
Spituk Monastery or Gompa is one of the nearest to Leh town, about 8 km from town
on the Leh-Srinagar Road, just beyond the Hall of Fame attraction. It is worth a visit

title: A memorable visit.
text:
Deskit monastery is one of the top places to visit at Nubra Valley. It is perhaps the oldest and largest monastery in the region. It is about 14 km from Hunder. As with most monasteries, it is at multiple levels on top of a hill. Near the base of the hill is a tall ( 100 ft+) statue of Maitreya Buddha has been completed relatively recently in 2010. In a visit to monastery start with this statue which is amazing.
The approach to the monastery is through a flight of steps to the prayer hall. At each level there are a number of prayer wheels which you should move in the clockwise direction as you enter. The monastery has statue of Cho Rinpoche (Crowned Buddha) in the prayer hall. After visiting the prayer hall don’t forget to rest and have tea with monks before you exit. There are sweet and salty (butter) tea options usually served with biscuits. From higher levels of monastery you can have glorious views of the Nubra valley bellow.
Definitely it was a memorable visit

title: A Beautiful sight from the road above or down below near the river
text: The confluence of the Indus and Zanskar river is a wonderful sight. It is on the Leh -Kargil road close to Nimu. It can be great place to take pictures from the road above. But take selfies close to the edge. If you reach in season it is a place where you also do white river rafting.
place: Confluence of the Indus and Zanskar Rivers
